results.title: An Interview with Wes Bailey
results.brief_description: With a vibrant sense of humour, Wes Bailey recounts his various postings as a signaller during World War II. Long hot days of being eaten alive by mozzies as well as the expected pleasures of fruit and vegetables have nothing on the most significant posting of Bailey’s career, as husband to fellow signaller Phil Bailey.
results.description: With a vibrant sense of humour, Wes Bailey recounts his various postings as a signaller during World War II. results.title: Tusalava
results.brief_description: 1. Lye’s first film was originally accompanied by live music by Jack Ellit. No score was ever found, so the film presented here is silent, a vision of the beginnings of life on earth - mixing Maori, silent and modernist influences.

results.title: An Interview with Alan Clark
results.brief_description: On the 16th May, 1941, Alan Clark was called up to serve for Australia in World War II. He tells of his time training in New South Wales, his decision to join the Air Force and the precise skill involved with dropping mines.
results.description: On the 16th May, 1941, Alan Clark was called up to serve for Australia in World War II. He tells of his time training in New South Wales, his decision to join the Air Force and the precise skill involved with dropping mines.

results.title: Signals : nerves of the army
results.creator_credit: Bruce Christie, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: During the war, without communication, the soldiers were sitting ducks. Signalmen, like Bruce Christie, may not have been on the front line, but, as Bruce illustrates, their role was just as crucial to the war.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bruce Christie, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Reviewing the Australian New Wave panel discussion with David Stratton

video_links.name: Reviewing the Australian New Wave panel discussion with David Stratton

results.brief_description: The 1960s brought on a change in government in Australia, resulting in greater funding towards the arts and Australia’s film industry in particular. In turn, this political change gave rise to what was to be called the ‘Australian New Wave’ in cinema. Celebrated film critic, David Stratton, shares his recollections of this pivotal time with fellow key players: Jan Chapman, Matt Carroll, Paul Cox and Phillip Noyce (via SKYPE). This panel discussion was filmed at ACMI as part of the ‘Margaret and David: 25 years talking movies’ exhibition.
results.title_for_label: Reviewing the Australian New Wave panel discussion with David Stratton
results.description: The 1960s brought on a change in government in Australia, resulting in greater funding towards the arts and Australia’s film industry in particular. In turn, this political change gave rise to what was to be called the ‘Australian New Wave’ in cinema. Celebrated film critic, David Stratton, shares his recollections of this pivotal time with fellow key players: Jan Chapman, Matt Carroll, Paul Cox and Phillip Noyce (via SKYPE). This panel discussion was filmed at ACMI as part of the ‘Margaret and David: 25 years talking movies’ exhibition.

This panel discussion was filmed at ACMI as part of the ‘Margaret and David: 25 years talking movies’ exhibition.

results.title: The Yellow-box eucalypt
results.creator_credit: Des Surkitt, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Des Surkitt pays tribute to the 27 fallen soldiers in one of the worst accidents in the Australian Army’s history. In Kapooka, an explosion during a training exercise, took the lives of all but one of the young soldiers. This event had a profound effect on Des, more so as he had just completed the training program the week before. Despite his good fortune, Des honours these lost men and reflects on why they have been forgotten by their own country.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Des Surkitt, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Neal Benezra 21st Century Museums: SFMOMA Looking Forward
results.creator_credit: Public Programs - Events (Helen Simondson) and ACMI

video_links.name: Neal Benezra 21st Century Museums: SFMOMA Looking Forward

results.brief_description:
Neal Benezra, director of San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (SFMOMA), talks about the history of the institution with regards to its upcoming expansion. Benezra tells the story of his journey to find the architects who designed the expansion and explains the thinking behind the vision for the building.

This talk featured as part of the ‘William Kentridge: Five Themes’ exhibition public programs events. The exhibition was originally curated by SFMOMA in 2009 and has since travelled to New York, Paris, Vienna, Jerusalem and Moscow.
results.title_for_label: Neal Benezra 21st Century Museums: SFMOMA Looking Forward

This talk featured as part of the ‘William Kentridge: Five Themes’ exhibition public programs events. The exhibition was originally curated by SFMOMA in 2009 and has since travelled to New York, Paris, Vienna, Jerusalem and Moscow.
